title: 106_hr942
content: The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" is cited as the short title. It includes a revision of duopoly rules in the Communications Act of 1934. The Commission is limited in prohibiting ownership of two stations with overlapping coverage contours in separate television markets or two television stations in the same market, with one being a UHF station. Existing local marketing agreements between two broadcast television stations in the same market are exempt from the duopoly rule. In exceptional cases, ownership of two VHF stations may be permitted by the Commission. The Commission may allow ownership of two VHF television stations in the same market if it does not harm competition or media diversity. SEC. 3. CROSS-OWNERSHIP LIMITATIONS. The Federal Communications Commission is required to make rule changes regarding ownership limitations for broadcast station licenses and the one-to-a-market rule. Minority voting stock interests will not be considered a cognizable interest in certain cases. Cable cross-ownership limitations under the Communications Act of 1934 are also amended. The Federal Communications Commission is revising regulations to allow ownership interests in both broadcasting stations and cable systems serving the same community. Additionally, the Commission will permit television broadcast stations to affiliate with entities controlling multiple networks, with a deadline set for completing all necessary actions. The Federal Communications Commission will complete necessary modifications within 90 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4 amends the Telecommunications Act of 1996 to increase the limit on FCC authority to 45 percent. The FCC must implement this change within 90 days. SEC. 5 addresses reciprocal treatment of foreign ownership restrictions. Subsection (b) of section 310 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. No licenses shall be granted to aliens, foreign corporations, or corporations with significant foreign ownership. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. Licenses cannot be granted to aliens, foreign corporations, or corporations with significant foreign ownership. The FCC may refuse or revoke a license if it is held by entities with ties to foreign governments, but may grant licenses if reciprocal treatment is provided to US corporations in foreign countries. The Communications Act of 1934 restricts foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. The FCC may permit foreign entities to own a portion of a broadcast station's capital stock, up to 40%, if reciprocal treatment is provided to US corporations in that foreign country. The term 'United States person' includes corporations organized under US laws and US citizens. The Communications Act of 1934 limits foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. Foreign entities can own up to 40% of a broadcast station's capital stock with FCC approval, as long as US corporations receive similar treatment in that foreign country. The term 'United States person' includes US corporations and citizens.
